Good Question

Interacting with online community and getting an answers for a question

Welcome. Good Question service guides you asking questions in online discussion geared towards solving technical matters. Please spend two minutes to read advices below.

You are most likely arrived here for community discussion. If you are new to online discussion, please spend half a minute reading instructions below how to make sure you get better input from the community.

Every question needs context

Tell about why you ended up dealing with the question. It is easier for people tp relate your to problem when they have more context available.

More info
  • Who are you? People will spend more effort to help you if you tell upfront that you are inexperienced, student or doing this voluntary instead of for your work. By knowing your experience level, people don't make failed assumptions how technically deep answers you can understand.
  • How did you end up doing this? Usually the technical problem is just an obstacle towards a greater goal. But you might have taken wrong route. Tell your larger goal and why you ended up with this problem. It might be that you have a wrong angle to the problem in the first place.
  • What did you try this far? Tell what have you done already to try to solve the problem. With slim voluntary resources answering the question initiative in problem solving is appreciated.

Be specific

Use available tools to make sure you can share technical details related to your problem.

More info
  • Have steps, commands or code. Share the source code of the problem. Make it easy for people to understand exact commands or steps how to repeat the
  • Have logs. If your problem creates a output, to a terminal or log files, have a full excerpt to sharein a service like pastie.org. Don't paste directly in the chats as this would create noise affecting people discussing other matters simultaneously.
  • Demostrate the problem. If your problem is related to pure HTML, CSS and JavaScript it can be repeated in a browser. Put up a related test case in a collaborate debugging service like jsfiddle.net or CodePen When people can confirm and repeat the problem in their own browser it is very easy them to help you.

Be patient

Wait for the answer patiently, don't repeat your question. People might be monitoring community chat only once in an hour.

More info
  • Be prepared to wait for the answer. Have the chat open at least this an hour to see if anyone can answer to your question.
  • People might not be online. Large number of chat participants doesn't mean that those people are at the front of the computer. Also, consider timing: weekends and evening are usually more quiet.
  • Try alternative non-real-time forums. If you don't get any answers in chat try non-real-time forums. If you are looking for a off-the-shelf answer for a specific question try stackoverflow.com (programming) and related StackExchange Q&A sites. Often a community also has an public mailing list or a forum where you can post your question and wait for few days for the answer.

Don't compete for attentation

Don't ask permission to ask questions. Don't expect personal councelling or send private messages to people unless they know you. Greet, ask your question, wait for the answer and enjoy smalltalk meanwhile.

More info
  • Metaquestions are pointless. Asking permission to ask question or asking if someone generally knows about a topic does not contain any details which might raise interest towards your issue. Go directly to the point of the matter you want to discuss.
  • Your problem is not critical for other people. Extra pleases and pledges won't change the factual content of your question making it quicker for answer to other people. They only add noise to the discussion channel.
  • If people can help you they will react to your question. Sending private messages to people or asking a personal mentoring could be considered rude.

Participate

Be prepared to spend time with the online community. Learning to know people will increase mutual trust.

More info
  • Facetime matters. When people know and trust you it is easier for them to help you. They know your background, timezone, skill level, character and way to discussing and vice versa. More time you spend with the community, easier it becomes to get questions and answers.
  • Leave chat running. The best way to participate online discussion is to use an IRC client which is connected to the chat all time and tolerant to disconnects. See what options you have.
  • Help others. If you only join the discussion to ask your own question, but not for helping with the problems of other people you are effectively sucking community resources making the community net loss for everybody. In long term this will erode the community.
  • Do smalltalk. Even if the disucssion is technical and factual by the nature it helps to build a character which jokes and other comments which might cheer up people having bad time solving their issues.
People answer questions in online communities voluntary. They do it, because they love what they do. But they are only human; they have limited knowledge and bad moods for unrelated reasons. Making it easy for people to like what they do will make it easier for them to help you.
